column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Future of the WWW
#Text=I 've read that scientists at CERN are currently working on grid computing , mainly to process the huge amounts of data from the Large Hadron Collider project .
#Text=Do you think grid computing will be the next generation web ?
#Text=Are there restrictions that limit the use of grid computing , for example working over large distances ?
#Text=About grid computing
#Text=I have not much to say .
#Text=The first intention of the ARPANET and later the intenet was the use of computing resources at a distance .
#Text=Grid computing is an extrapolation of that idea .
#Text=I do n't know if the average user will use grid computing .
#Text=Most probably not .
#Text=It seems to me that personal computing stands to grid computing like serial computing stands to parallel computing .
#Text=There are useful applications of parallel computing , but I do n't think my second processor is busy while I 'm typing this .
#Text=Grid computing can be used behind the scenes in certain services , but I find it hard to see what the web surfer will use it for .
#Text=Google knows what to do with it , I 'm sure .
#Text=So I 'll shut up about it .
#Text=You 've said before that you do n't care a lot about the concept of web 2.0 , because it was something you envisioned from the beginning , and it was something bound to happen : correct ?
#Text=If not , what is your vision for The Web ?
#Text=What would be a real web Renaissance ?
#Text=Freely contributing to web content was one of the original goals : the web should be as easy to write as it is to read .
#Text=Another function we lost due to too fast development .
#Text=— Robert Cailliau
#Text=Web 2.0 is something that indeed " exists " , but it is not a technology .
#Text=It is a social phenomenon that requires the simultaneous deployment of a number of technologies to build the so-called 2.0 websites .
#Text=Delivering web content via blogs and the like is a " new " happening in which the individual participates , often in very original ways .
#Text=Freely contributing to web content was one of the original goals : the web should be as easy to write as it is to read .
#Text=Another function we lost due to too fast development .
#Text=I 'm much more worried about data .
#Text=All my data are on my home computer and I regularly back them up .
#Text=I have nothing important on a server : no e-mail , no photos , videos or whatever .
#Text=But I 'm an exception : most people never back up their machines and actually cannot handle a computer .
#Text=They use the machine as a terminal to the internet .

#Text=Services such as gmail , YouTube , and in fact every site having some kind of " My- ... " where one leaves a bit of oneself , bring us back to the archaic model of computing : central mainframes and storage , used through terminals on which no local applications run .
